title.text: Evaluation Measures for Detection of Personal Health Information

abstractContent.text: Texts containing personal health information reveal enough data fora third party to be able to identify an individual and his health condition.
Detection of personal health information in electronic health records is an essential part of record de-identification.

entities.text: Detection of personal health information in electronic health

abstractContent.text: Performance evaluation in use today focuses on method's ability to identify whether a word reveals personal health information or not.
In this study, we propose and show that the multi-label classification measures better serve the final goal of the record de-identification.

introductionContent.text: Removing personal data in documents with sensitive contents aims to protect privacy of an individual from a third party and is called deidentification process.

entities.text: Removing personal data in documents with sensitive contents

introductionContent.text: De-identification of electronic health records (EHR) became an important task of applied Health Informatics (.
Properly deidentified EHR, if revealed to a third party, will not identify the patient and his health conditions.
De-identification can be viewed as personal health information (PHI) detection, followed by alternation of the retrieved information (.
The first phase, PHI detection, uses Supervised Machine Learning, Natural Language Processing and Information Extraction techniques (.
Name, date of birth, address, health insurance number are examples of PHI that should be detected:,, was admitted to the with chest pain and respiratory insufficiency.
The present paper focuses on evaluation practices of PHI detection.
Ordinary, the quality of PHI detection is measured in counts that record correctly and incorrectly recognized PHI words and word combinations.
presents a confusion matrix for binary classification; tp are true PHI, fp -false PHI, fn -false non-PHI, and tntrue non-PHI counts.

Accuracy, Precision, Recall, Fscore are used to assess PHI detection . It is a common practice to evaluate detection as a binary classification of word categories (e.g., accuracy of name classification in a set of EHR).

In this study, we argue that treating PHI detection as binary word classification does not fully meet the needs of the de-identification process.

entities.text: PHI detection as binary word classification

introductionContent.text: We instead formulate the PHI detection as a multilabel document classification, where performance is assessed through per-document multi-class classification.
We propose that the multi-label document classification better serves the final goal of the EHR de-identification.
We present a case study where Exact Match Ratio, Labelling Fscore, Hamming Loss, One-error are used to assess the PHI detection results.
